pageTitle: Public holidays in China - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {6814=From at least 2000 until this reform, the Spring Festival public holiday began on New Year's Day itself. From 2008 to 2013 it was shifted back by one day to begin on Chinese New Year's Eve. In 2014, New Year's Eve became a working day again, which provoked hostile discussion by netizens and academics.[1][10], 6210=There was a major reform in 2008, abolishing the Labour Day Golden Week and adding three traditional Chinese holidays (Qingming Festival, Duanwu Festival, and Mid-Autumn Festival).[9], 24774=The closeness of Labor Day and Youth Day resulted in an unexpectedly long break for schools in 2008 - the Youth Day half-holiday entitlement had been largely forgotten because it has been subsumed into the Golden Week., 7916=The Chinese New Year and National Day holidays are three days long. The week-long holidays on May (Labor) Day and National Day began in 2000, as a measure to increase and encourage holiday spending. The resulting seven-day holidays are called "Golden Weeks" (黄金周), and have become peak seasons for travel and tourism. In 2008, the Labor Day holiday was shortened to one day to reduce travel rushes to just twice a year, and instead three traditional Chinese holidays were added., 35805=Some Chinese young adults have begun to celebrate 11 November as Singles Day (Chinese: 光棍节; pinyin: guāng gùn jié) because of the many ones (1s) in the date.[11]}
textBeforeTable: There are currently seven official public holidays in China. Each year's holidays are announced about three weeks before the start of the year by the General Office of the State Council. A notable feature of mainland Chinese holidays is that weekends are usually swapped with the weekdays next to the actual holiday to create a longer vacation period. The public holiday pattern, described as "notoriously complicated" by a Wall Street Journal journalist,[1] is therefore less predictable than most developed countries. Public holidays in China (disambiguation). For other uses, see search navigation, Jump to:   (Redirected from Public holidays in the People's Republic of China) From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia Public holidays in China

Contents 1 Reforms 2 Transferred holidays 2.1 2010 example 3 Additional holidays for specific social groups 4 Traditional holiday scheme 5 Ethnic Minorities Holidays 6 Novel holidays 7 See also 8 Notes and references 9 References Reforms[edit] There was a major reform in 2008, abolishing the Labour Day Golden Week and adding three traditional Chinese holidays (Qingming Festival, Duanwu Festival, and Mid-Autumn Festival).[9] From at least 2000 until this reform, the Spring Festival public holiday began on New Year's Day itself.
